Award.AwardTitle: FMSG: Internet of People and Things Bridging manual to semiautomated processes through Cybermanufacturing Collaborative Intelligence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration: Abstract<br/><br/>This project supports fundamental research in understanding how human roles in manufacturing will evolve with the introduction of increasingly intelligent autonomous agents and what characteristics of assistive technology are important to provide the most effective collaborative relationship between humans and artificial intelligence systems. Application of this research will not only help reduce costs and improve quality for parts designed and manufactured in technical environments but will also explore the sociology of human interaction with artificial systems in ways that further human purposefulness and fulfillment in work. This project promotes the progress of interdependent science and advances national prosperity and welfare through facilitating value creating in future manufacturing systems. Additionally, this work includes a plan for broadening participation of underrepresented groups in scientific research by a targeted set of recruiting activities toward minority and female candidates through social media and peer-to-peer networks, as well as formal programs such as the National GEM consortium and Clemson's Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) programs.<br/><br/>The objectives of this project are to model collaboration strength in manufacturing among systems of people and artificial intelligence agents and to measure assistive technologiesâ€™ influence on manufacturing collaboration. As the manufacturing supply chain has grown from a progression of sequential parts creating an assembly to more modern networks of specialized module builders, the role of interorganizational and intraorganizational collaboration has grown immensely in its influence on productivity and profitability. Considering the advent of new intelligent planning, automation, and production systems, the proposing team conjectures that the strength of collaboration will retain its influence on positive manufacturing outcomes and can be affected significantly by assistive technologies for human participation. The project outcomes have important implications for future manufacturing in regard to the transition to artificial intelligence implementation throughout the supply chain, and lasting human presence in manufacturing; both of which must work in harmony.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: SOC STUDIES OF SCI, ENG & TECH
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this project were to model collaboration strength in manufacturing among systems of people and artificial intelligence agents and to measure assistive technologies? influence on manufacturing collaboration. As the manufacturing supply chain has grown from a progression of simple parts creating an assembly to more modern networks of specialized module builders, the role of interorganizational and intraorganizational collaboration has grown immensely in its influence on productivity and profitability. Considering the advent of new intelligent planning, automation, and production systems, the proposing team tested the hypothesis that the strength of human-artificial intelligence team collaboration is affected by assistive technologies for human participation.

The key intellectual contribution from the project has been a better understanding of the relationships among humans and intelligent agents from the perspective of team science. Teaming has been well explored for pairs and groups of human agents with automation technology as a tool. However, artificial intelligence approaches can augment not only physical work, but also decision-making, allowing consideration of such technologies as another team member. This project used team science to model the relationship between artificial intelligence level of assistance and the resultant team performance. It found increased AI agent responsibility could detract from team coordination if not properly designed and managed, so raising awareness of human-AI interactions will be important in future system designs. Additionally, a series of different industry focus groups with participants ranging from floor associates to upper-level managers revealed similar perceptions, that organizations share concerns in four main themes: lack of capable workforce, lack of engagement with the process, lack of data flow between worker and digital system, and worker acceptance and utilization of new technology.

The broader impacts of this work lie in the possibility to design improved artificial agents to support and integrate with teams of humans in production environments. The expected benefits are in both improved manufacturing productivity and quality, but perhaps more importantly in improved employee satisfaction and fulfillment because of clearer role definition and partitioning of responsibilities. This project also gave students from Psychology and Engineering the opportunity to train in AI technologies, interact directly with multiple manufacturing organizations to understand perceptions of AI concerns, and to bring lessons from this project into teams of undergraduate researchers.

Modified by: Laine Mears
